item.title: Animal Crossing: New Horizons Getting Free Update And Nintendo Switch 2 Edition
item.content:encoded:
It’s time to revisit the island. Nintendo has announced that Animal Crossing: New Horizons is the latest first-party game from the company to get a Nintendo Switch 2 Edition for players on the new system. In addition to the Switch 2 Edition, it was also revealed that a free content update is coming for all players.

Releasing on January 15, 2026, the Switch 2 Edition will be available for $64.99. If you already own the game, you can upgrade for just $4.99.

Included in the Switch 2 Edition of Animal Crossing: New Horizons are 4K visuals in TV mode, mouse controls with the right Joy-Con 2, an in-game megaphone that allows you to call for residents on the island, 12-player online sessions for other Switch 2 Edition players, and CameraPlay to see your friends as you play online.

A Free Update Is Coming For Everyone

As mentioned, there’s also a free update for all Animal Crossing: New Horizons players launching on the same day. The update, the game’s first major update since November 2021, includes a new resort hotel, a new reset feature, a multiplayer island, and more. You can check out the new additions for players below, courtesy of Nintendo.

Animal Crossing: New Horizons Update Details:

  • Resort Hotel’s Grand Opening: A resort hotel is opening on the pier, and it’s run by Kapp’n’s family. To bring in guests from off the island, you’ll help out by decorating guest rooms and more. Plus, find new furniture and clothing at the souvenir shop and dress up mannequins with outfits that guests can wear.
  • Making Island Life More Convenient: Want a fresh start? Resetti is on hand with a convenient Reset Service to help tidy up your island. Additionally, you can now upgrade your home storage to hold up to 9,000 items, and store trees, shrubs and flowers there, too.
  • Slumber Island: Players with a Nintendo Switch Online membershipcan design and save up to three islands and play with friends online. Select the size and layout of the island, build and design it collaboratively, access your inventory and decorate, plus invite residents from your home island.
  • Collaborations: Collect Nintendo items like the Ultra Hand and Nintendo consoles in-game to add some classic flair to your island. Nintendo Switch Online members can play select classic Nintendo titles in-game when interacting with specific Nintendo console items, too! LEGO® items will also make their debut with this update. And use select The Legend of Zeldaand Splatoonseries amiibo8 to invite certain characters — and unlock various items inspired by those series.

What do you think of the updates—both free and paid—coming to Animal Crossing: New Horizons? Leave your thoughts down in the comments, and join the official Insider Gaming Discord server.

item.title: The Outer Worlds 2 Trolls Players Who Buy The Game’s Premium Edition
item.content:encoded:
Obsidian Entertainment’s busy 2025 ends with the release of The Outer Worlds 2. If you’re committed to the series, you can upgrade to the Premium Edition to get more bang for your sci-fi buck. But doing so also comes with a great benefit and a bit of thinly-veiled banter.

With so many big releases toward the end of 2025, it’s easy to forget that The Outer Worlds 2 is sandwiched in between all of this. The first game was tremendous, and the sci-fi sequel is just as good, if not better. If you’re really keen, you can go all out for the Premium Edition.

The Outer Worlds 2 Premium Edition Comes With A ‘Flaw’

Chances are, you’ve already checked out all The Outer Worlds 2 Pre-Order Bonuses & Editions. The Premium Edition is the big, bad wolf of the pack. It comes with future DLC expansions, cosmetics, and a digital artbook and soundtrack. But one thing it doesn’t make clear is the Flaw you can gain from it.

The Outer Worlds 2 has many ‘Flaws,’ all of which give your character permanent attribute afflictions and benefits. The Consumerism Flaw is automatically presented to you for buying the Premium Edition.

“You’re the reason our marketing works. Promotions and sales have riddled your brain, and you’re more interested in buying the next big thing than in financial planning,” the Flaw’s description says.

If you accept the Flaw, you gain “-15% Vendor Prices” and “-10% Sell Value at Vendors.” It’s an optional Flaw, so you don’t have to take it, but Obsidian’s self-awareness and humor are very much appreciated on this one. Basically saying ‘We’re glad you bought our game’s most expensive edition, but praise capitalism!’

Have you picked up The Outer Worlds 2? Do you plan to? Let us know through the Insider Gaming Discord Server, which is getting more popular by the minute.

item.title: Former Halo Dev Criticizes “Lame” Remake Changes
item.content:encoded:
Halo: Campaign Evolved is the name of the long-awaited Combat Evolved remake. It brings Halo to PlayStation for the first time ever. However, one of the game’s original developers has noticed some discrepancies in the game’s early footage and questioned the changes, as they alter the game.

Time stood still when the Halo: Combat Evolved Remake was officially announced. Bungie’s original creation was about to become celebrated once more. This time, PlayStation 5 owners would get to experience history with Halo making its blue-brand debut. Not everyone is as thrilled with the game’s first footage, though.

Halo: Combat Evolved Remake Makes Key Changes From Original

Alongside the remake announcement, we also got to witness a special 13-minute gameplay demo. It showed off the game’s glorious opening minutes. The graphics look stunning, and it’s the Halo you know, but better.

Well, most people seem to think so. One person who’s not as impressed is former Bungie game designer Jaime Griesemer. The now-creative director at Highwire Games was responsible for numerous roles at Bungie, including designing, developing, tuning, and scripting gameplay objects, missions, core combat principles, and the tutorial and demo.

After seeing the new gameplay, here’s what Griesemer had to say on X:

“You aren’t supposed to be able to take the Warthog up to steamroll the Hunters. I intentionally placed rocks in the way so you had to fight them on foot. When you can just smash the crates out of the way it wrecks the encounters. But the worst part? They put trees in the landing area of the WooHoo Jump. Lame. @game_fabricator What have they done to beloved B30?!”

@game_fabricator being Marcus Lehto: Former co-creator of Halo, who was recently ‘Disappointed’ that he and various team members were omitted from the Battlefield 6 credits.

Griesemer replied to many commenters on the post. He understood that “You can FORCE the Warthog through the gap in a variety of ways. I literally spent most of a day making it discouraging and difficult but not impossible. You’re welcome!” and that “On further analysis I’m sure it’s because the vehicles take damage and so you’re just as likely to destroy the hog as get it over the rocks. If anything that makes it -worse- because -none- of the vehicle tricks are going to work anymore.”

The talking point here isn’t necessarily the changes made to Halo: Campaign Evolved (as it’s being called) and its first few minutes, but what other tweaks Halo Studios AKA 343 Industries, have made throughout the game.

Do you think this is a big deal? Are you worried about other sections of the game being changed? Let us know through the Insider Gaming Discord Server.

We already know more changes are afoot, as it’s confirmed that The Library Level is ‘Being Fixed’ for Halo: Campaign Evolved.
